page.title: 04HISTORIC BUILDINGS IN BUNGAY
page.content: In the Bungay Conservation Area there are 182 buildings including churches of architecteral or historical value. Earsham Hall was first built in 1560. It has a lake in 16 acres of land.There was once a school in the Hall,but it is now a home.Three hundred years ago, Mettingham Castle-built in 1342-housed a college.The Castle is now in ruins, part of it has been made into a farm. The house inside the grounds is late Victorian.Bungay Castle was built by Bigod in 1165.All that remains today are the foundations up to the level of the ground floor windows and twin towers.The Buttercross is a dome supported by pillars.On top is a figure of Justice.Prisoners were once kept beneath the dome but now it is the centre of the market place. 'Justice' is {NOT blind-folded}.
